quantityRules.description: Social species - best in groups of 4-8. Provide 20 gallons for first 2-3 frogs, add 10 gallons per additional 2 frogs. Pair ratio: 2 males per 1 female for breeding.

humidity.notes: Average 70-75% daytime with peaks of 90-95% at night during misting. Never keep above 75% continuously during day (bacterial skin infections risk). Well-ventilated setup essential.

careTargets.gradient: Subtle vertical gradient with cooler water (72-76¬∞F) and slightly warmer canopy (74-80¬∞F)

temperament: Social and docile, minimal handling recommended
setupTips: Vertical paludarium setup required - height more important than floor space
Semi-aquatic species - MUST have both land and water sections (not optional)
Best kept in groups of 4-8 for natural social behavior and breeding displays
Provide extensive climbing space with branches, cork, vines positioned diagonally
Dense foliage with sturdy leaves required for resting/hiding during day
Create riparian zone (land-water interface) with easy access points
Use Bio Drain substrate with mesh, topped with Sub Stratum + Plantation Soil + forest moss
notes: Breeding ratio: 2 males per 1 female encourages healthy competition
Excellent for paludarium builds - naturally humid environment supports live plants
30+ years of successful captive breeding - readily available captive-bred specimens
Uses 'startle coloration' defense - when threatened, flashes bright blue/yellow side coloring and red eyes to shock predators
Tadpoles can hatch early if they detect vibrations from predators (snakes/wasps) - survival adaptation allowing escape before being eaten

warnings.message: Stable temperature essential - very narrow range (75-85¬∞F day, 68-75¬∞F night). Avoid overheating in summer.
Clean water mandatory for soaking and breeding. Always treat tap water with Aquatize. Bi-weekly partial water changes (25-33%) required.
Never keep humidity above 75% continuously - causes bacterial skin infections. Ensure excellent ventilation despite high humidity needs.
Minimal handling only - sensitive skin and agile leapers. Risk of injury from falls. Skin secretions can irritate eyes.
Social species - keep in groups of 4-8 for natural behavior. Single frogs may be stressed and inactive.
Paludarium setup required (not standard terrarium). Must provide both substantial water section and land area with climbing space.
Can be picky eaters - may refuse certain insects initially. Offer variety and train for tweezer feeding. Takes time to adjust.
Crepuscular/nocturnal - most active dawn/dusk. Don't disturb during day when sleeping on leaves.
Will breed readily if provided proper rainy season simulation (increased misting, temperature adjustments). Eggs laid on leaves above water.

feedingRequirements: Feed variety of live insects: crickets, roaches, fruit flies, waxworms
Dust all insects with calcium + D3
Can train to accept canned insects with tweezer feeding
waterNotes: Clean water section required for soaking and breeding
Always treat tap water with dechlorinator
Frogs drink by absorbing water through skin
